Ultimately, the total CAPEX in 2026 will amount to approximately $750 billion, up $350 billion from 2025 and $510 billion from 2024. Nevertheless, one should bear in mind that the primary source of CAPEX financing is not profit, but long-term debt. Companies included in the Nasdaq-100 are increasing their credit leverage themselves, driven by the strategic need to quickly enter new AI sub-sectors. 2026 will see a continuation of the boom, with no room for a slow entry, since any delay in scaling up will result in the market being divided among investors who have invested more in development in a few years' time. It is precisely for this reason that the management of the largest IT giants continues to opt for increasing debt to finance CAPEX, and does not seek ways to optimize through self-financing. Even though the market is still wondering what the return on AI investments will be, because the infrastructure is being built today and the real ROI won't be known for a few years, the negative scenario will still take time to happen. For now, as the market momentum remains bullish, because monetization is beginning and margins remain unchanged, continue to bet on QQQI, the double-digit return of which now outweighs the potential risks from the uncertainty surrounding the Nasdaq-100.

Risks of the investment thesis

Investing in QQQI is still risky because it hasn't been tested in a really bearish market. For example, if the Nasdaq-100 drops more than 20-30% over 6-12 months, it's not clear how the fund's capital will hold up. This is because, under such circumstances, any premium generated by the option strategy is unlikely to cover more than half of the drawdown. In addition, it is precisely in such cases that further income generated may be reduced due to capital erosion, because the fund will have less capital to work with. Correspondingly, NAV decline could lead to even greater risks for investments in QQQI, thereby making it a less reliable ETF. One exception to this negative scenario could be that the bear market causes growth and market volatility, on which the size of the potential premium from selling options depends. Under such circumstances, profits generated from the option strategy may increase, improving the situation with NAV recovery. I would like to caution, though, in the event of a Nasdaq-100 reversal, the QQQI will definitely not be considered a hedging instrument against its decline, so it may be worth considering other assets.

Conclusion

As a result, even though analysts and economists are talking about more risks, it's still my opinion that the market won't crash in 2026 thanks to the massive CAPEX that's keeping the AI supercycle going. That is why I believe QQQI remains an attractive investment fund that targets double-digit dividend yields and offers tax optimization benefits. Nevertheless, from a long-term perspective, investors should exercise greater caution when maintaining income-oriented assets in their portfolios that are highly correlated with the performance of the Nasdaq-100 and Mag-7 stocks individually. That's why, should we encounter real data confirming unjustified demand for AI products and ROI from investments in data centers and network infrastructure, we'll be prepared to optimize the portfolio, which will most likely exclude ETFs such as QQQI.

data.title: Cal-Maine Foods Ended Up More Than I Thought It Would Crack Up To Be (Rating Upgrade)
data.description:
Acknowledging when you are wrong is one of the most important things, not only when it comes to investing, but when it comes to life in general. Being humble about your mistakes is how you learn and grow. A great example of this involving myself relates to my decision, back in April of 2022, to rate Cal-Maine Foods (CALM) a 'sell.' Leading up to that point, declining sales, profits, and cash flows, had dominated the financial narrative. Admittedly, the company was low risk because of its strong balance sheet. But the stock looked drastically overpriced. I underestimated, quite frankly, just what would happen in the egg market that the company operates in. I did not foresee prices skyrocketing because of industry supply constraints. That ultimately pushed revenue, profits, and cash flows, drastically higher. And as a result, the company's stock price has risen 81.9% at a time when the S&P 500 is up only 50.2%.

This was one of the biggest misses that I have had in the last couple of years. Looking at the picture today, I see a company that is continuing to benefit from elevated prices. But make no mistake that these price increases are likely temporary. Data from the USDA suggests that prices will drop throughout 2026. And in fact, for the 2026 fiscal year for the company, we have already seen a deleterious impact on the bottom line as a result. Having said that, the stock is incredibly cheap right now. And its balance sheet is remarkably robust. I wouldn't go so far as to upgrade the stock to a 'buy' because of worries over declining prices. But I do think that rating it a very solid 'hold' makes sense here.

The picture is better than I thoughts

Some companies in the food industry are incredibly diverse from an operational standpoint. And others, such as Cal-Maine Foods, are much more concentrated. The company prides itself on being the largest producer and distributor of shell eggs in the US. Its operations consist of hatching chicks, growing and maintaining flocks of pullets, dealing with layers and breeders, producing feed, and ultimately producing and distributing eggs. The company is massive in this industry. According to management, the fleet as of the end of the most recent quarter consisted of 11.4 million pullets and breeders, as well as 49.3 million layers.

Over the last few years, financial performance for the business has been admittedly mixed. In the chart above, you can see financial results for the 2023 through 2025 fiscal years. Revenue has certainly been lumpy. And profits and cash flows have responded in kind. What matters most, however, is that in 2025, the company achieved significant revenue that far exceeded what it had achieved in prior fiscal years. In the chart below, you can see results for the first half of the 2026 fiscal year compared to the same time of 2025. In this case, revenue, profits, and most cash flow metrics, pulled back.

These results have changed a lot, based primarily on changes in egg prices. You see, the vast majority of the company's revenue, approximately 85% for the first half of 2026, came specifically from the sale of shell eggs. Normally when you see rapid revenue growth like what was experienced over the last couple of years, it's because of continued investments aimed at boosting output. Yes, the company has achieved some expansion on that front. From 2023 through 2025, the firm went from selling 1.15 billion dozens of eggs to selling 1.28 billion dozens of eggs. And for the first half of 2026, the 640.2 million dozens of eggs produced by the company exceeded the 639.8 million dozen reported the previous year.

The bigger expansion for the company came from a hike in average prices for shell eggs. Back in 2023, prices averaged $2.62 per dozen. That dropped to $1.93 in 2024 before surging to $3.13 last year. Unfortunately, an outbreak of bird flu drastically slashed supplies of layers in the space. According to one source, since 2022, tens of millions of commercial egg layers have been impacted. This naturally caused a decline in overall supply, while demand remained robust. After all, eggs still remain a major source of protein at an affordable price. So when alternative options are still more expensive, demand remains resilient. We have started to see prices decline. In the first half of the 2026 fiscal year, they dropped to $2.25 per dozen. That's down from the $2.57 per dozen reported a year earlier.

The company also continues to benefit from expansion elsewhere. Even though the production and sale of shell eggs represents the main source of revenue growth for the company, it is investing heavily into the egg products and prepared foods markets. Examples here include hard-cooked eggs, egg wraps, protein pancakes, crepes, and wrap-ups. In that vein, in September of 2024, the company made an investment in Crepini LLC, essentially establishing a new egg products and prepared foods joint venture. And in the 2025 fiscal year, the business acquired Echo Lake Foods in a deal valued at $258 million. That business, based out of Wisconsin, produces, packages, markets, and distributes, prepared foods such as waffles, pancakes, scrambled eggs, frozen cooked omelets, egg patties, toast, and diced eggs.

These activities have helped to boost revenue for the prepared foods and egg products spaces as of late. Prior to the 2026 fiscal year, management never broke out these two separate categories. In the chart above, you can see expansion in revenue for them combined over the last two fiscal years. And in the chart below, you can see revenue figures for them when it comes to the first half of 2026 compared to the first half of 2025. Although this is great to see, it's not going to represent the largest portion of the company and its health. A lot will still depend on shell egg production and prices associated with them.

If we project out results for the company based on what was seen in the first half of 2026, we would expect net profits for the fiscal year to be around $998.8 million. Adjusted operating cash flow would be $1.25 billion, while EBITDA would amount to $1.38 billion. Using these estimates, and also the results that the company achieved for the 2025 fiscal year, we can see in the chart below how the stock is priced at the moment. Honestly, these are incredibly low multiples. And compared to other companies that are in the food space, which the chart below illustrates, the stock is definitely the cheapest of the group. Add on top of this the fact that it has a net cash position of $1.14 billion compared to a market capitalization of only $3.96 billion, and we are looking at an incredibly healthy company trading on the cheap.

Normally in cases like this, I would be incredibly bullish. In fact, I would typically be buying the stock hand over fist. However, I am concerned about prices moving forward. After seeing table eggs drop from 7.74 billion pounds in 2024 to 7.37 billion pounds in 2025, which would be a decline of 4.8% year over year, it's expected, according to the USDA, for overall egg production to shoot up to 7.90 billion pounds in the US this year. Prices are forecasted to fall drastically.

Grade A large eggs, for instance, should see prices drop from $3.74 per dozen last year to $1.20 per dozen this year. That will absolutely have an impact on the bottom line results for the company and likely means that the valuation data that I applied for 2026 is higher than what will ultimately be achieved. Of course, even if profits and cash flows are cut by half, we are still looking at a company that is attractively priced. But because of the uncertainty that exists here, I think a more cautious approach to valuing the company is warranted.

One thing that will work in the company's favor as time goes on is that management continues to make investments in transforming the operation. I already talked about its move into the egg products and prepared foods space. But that's not all. Within the shell egg category, for instance, the company continues to transition away from conventional eggs and towards specialty ones. In the second quarter of 2026, 44% of shell egg sales were specialty eggs. That's up from 32% a year earlier. This is important because, in addition to experiencing higher demand, specialty eggs also demand higher prices. Take the second quarter of the 2026 fiscal year as an example. During that quarter, conventional shell egg prices averaged $1.80 per dozen. That was down drastically from the $2.94 per dozen reported the previous year. But year over year, specialty egg prices dropped only slightly from $2.39 per dozen to $2.37 per dozen.

Management is making organic investments into the prepared foods side of the business also. In fact, the company recently launched a $15 million network optimization and capacity expansion project aimed at adding 17 million pounds annually of scrambled eggs production by the middle of the 2027 fiscal year. And on top of this, it's also investing $14.8 million into its high-speed pancake line. If everything goes according to plan, this should boost capacity for that product line by 12 million pounds through early fiscal 2027. When you add on top of this the fact that the aforementioned joint venture, Crepini Foods, will see the company invest $7 million through the 2028 fiscal year to add 18 million pounds of capacity, we are looking at significant capacity growth over the next couple of years.

Management also continues to focus on returning capital to shareholders. In fact, the company is currently paying out about a third of all net profits to the investor base in the form of dividends. The company also has a $500 million share buyback program in place. And in the first half of the 2026 fiscal year, the company bought back 846,037 shares in exchange for $74.8 million. That leaves $375.2 million remaining under its buyback initiative.

Takeaway

Based on all the data provided, I must say that I am definitely intrigued by Cal-Maine Foods right now. The company is certainly a high-quality business with very little in the way of solvency or liquidity risk. In fact, it is remarkably stable. I like seeing the investments being made by management. Diversifying away from conventional eggs is certainly a wise idea, especially considering their commoditized nature and volatility. Because of how cheap the stock is, it's difficult not to be bullish. But I do think that, based on the picture and its totality, the company deserves a very solid 'hold' rating. It would be higher if not for worries over declining egg prices. But for now, a more cautious approach is justified.

data.title: 10 Best CEFs This Month: Average Yield Of 9.7% (February 2026)
data.description:
Introduction:

Since Nov. 2025, the market has been mostly trading in a tight range between S&P 500 (SPX) levels 6600 and 6950. However, the S&P500 did cross the SPX7000 level briefly in January, but it has not done so in any meaningful way. There have been so many developments in the last month or so, ranging from cooling inflation, the Fed holding interest rates steady, the tariff situation in light of the Supreme Court order, and the evolving geopolitical situation around Iran. On top of that, the AI overvaluations and overborrowing have gripped the markets for some time. Also, fear of the AI impacts on software stocks has resulted in brutal revaluations and may be overdone. The outperformance of the foreign markets (over the U.S. market) and rotation of big money from technology to industrial, materials, energy, and utility sectors is continuing.

The further progress and direction of the market may also depend on the actions of the Fed. You can see the current odds of the Fed's next rate cut here on the CME FedWatchTool website.

All that being said, it is always hard to find anything that has both the quality and the low valuation, so buying the best of the income investments regularly in small quantities is the key. As always, investors have to tread carefully amid all the uncertainties.

Why CEFs?

The broader market, as represented by the S&P500, provides a dismal level of yield of less than 1.10%. Income investors and retirees can't survive on that level of income unless they have a very large pool of capital. Also, the method of raising income by selling shares is generally very stressful and full of pitfalls, and that's why it is not recommended. Alternatively, one can find solid blue-chip individual dividend stocks that pay much higher dividends than the S&P 500. They can also provide market-matching growth on a longer-term basis. To identify such stocks, we also publish a monthly article on the '5 Best DGI stocks'. You can find the most recent one here.

However, with CEFs, we can take the income to the next level. That said, they generally come with higher risks (discussed later), so we believe that an allocation of 20% to 30% to a diversified CEF portfolio should be good enough for most income investors. In summary, these investments should be used primarily for income, not growth.

We publish this monthly article on CEFs (Closed-end funds) to provide our readers with a select list of 10 CEFs that, as a group, provide wide diversification in terms of underlying assets, solid long-term performance at least on a relative basis, and are trading at decent valuations. Above all, the income goal for the group is to provide a yield of at least 8% or higher.

This month, as a group, the selected 10 best funds are offering an average distribution rate of 8.70% (as of 01/16/2026). Besides excellent distributions, these funds have had an excellent record over the long term and collectively returned 17.7%, 12.2%, and 13.3% (annualized) in the last three, five years, and 10 years, respectively. The average discount (to NAV) is attractive, at -7.5%. Since this is a monthly series, some selections may overlap from month to month.

Why Is It Important To Have A Diversified CEF Portfolio?

We believe a well-diversified CEF portfolio should contain at least 10 CEFs, preferably from different asset classes. It's also advisable to build the portfolio over a period rather than invest in one lump sum. If you were to invest in one CEF every month for a year, you would have a well-diversified CEF portfolio by the year's end. What we provide here every month is a list of ten probable candidates for further research. A CEF portfolio can be an important component of the overall portfolio strategy. One should preferably have a DGI portfolio as the foundation, and the CEF portfolio could be used to boost the income level to the desired level. How much should one allocate to CEFs? Each investor needs to answer this question himself/herself based on their personal situation and factors like the size of the portfolio, income needs, risk appetite, or risk tolerance.

Criteria to Shortlist:

Criteria

Brings down the number of funds to...

Reason for the Criteria

Baseline expense < 2.5% and Avg. Daily Volume > 10,000

Approx. 435 Funds

We do not want funds that charge excessive fees. Also, we want funds that have fair liquidity.

Market capitalization> 100 Million

Approx. 400 Funds

We do not want funds that are too small.

Track record/ History longer than five years (inception date 2016 or earlier)

Approx. 375 Funds

We want funds that have a reasonably long track record.

Discount/Premium < +7%

Approx. 350 Funds

We do not want to pay too high a premium; we want bigger discounts.

Distribution (dividend) Rate > 5%

Approx. 250-290 Funds

The current distribution (income) is reasonably high.

5-Year Annualized Return on NAV > 0% AND/ OR

3-Year Annualized Return on NAV >0%

Approx. 200-250 Funds

We want funds with a reasonably good past track record in maintaining their NAVs.

After we applied the above criteria this month, we are generally left with around 250 funds (plus or minus 5%) on our list. From here on, we apply our other criteria to narrow the list.

Note: All tables in this article have been created by the author (unless explicitly specified). Most of the data in this article is sourced from Cefconnect.com, Cefa.com, and Morningstar.com.

Narrowing Down To 50 Funds:

To narrow down the number of funds to a more manageable count, we will shortlist ten funds based on each of the following criteria. Thereafter, we will apply certain qualitative criteria to each fund and rank them to select the top five.

At this stage, we also eliminate certain funds with substantially negative NAV returns for both three-year and five-year periods.

Seven Broad Criteria:

  • Excess discount/premium (explained below).
  • Distribution rate.
  • Return on NAV, last three years (medium-term).
  • Return on NAV, last five years (long term).
  • Coverage ratio.
  • Excess return over distributions.
  • The total weight (calculated up to this point).

Excess Discount/Premium

We certainly like funds that are offering large discounts (not premiums) to their NAVs. But what's important is to look at the "excess discount/premium" and not the absolute value. We want to see the discount (or premium) relative to their past record, say, a 52-week average.

Excess Discount/Premium = Current Discount/Premium (Minus) 52-Wk Avg. Discount/ Premium.

For more explanation of the excess discount and z-scores, please refer to our blog post (link provided at the beginning of the article).

We sort our list (of approx. 250 funds) on the "excess discount/premium" in descending order. For this criterion, the lower the value, the better it is. So, we select the top 10 funds (with the most negative values) from this sorted list.

(All data as of 02/20/2026)

Table 1:

High Current Distribution Rate

After all, most investors invest in CEF funds for their juicy distributions. Even though we should not chase yield, at this stage, we want to give them a fair representation in our list and subject them to a more rigorous criterion later on. We sorted our list on the current distribution rate (descending order, highest at the top) and selected the top 10 funds from this sorted list.

Table 2:

Medium-Term Return on NAV (last three years)

We then sort our list on a three-year return on NAV (in descending order, highest at the top) and select the top 10 funds. For this reason, we make a shortlist based on the total score and keep only a few of them on this list.

Table 3:

Five-Year Annualized Return on NAV

We then sorted our list on the five-year return on NAV (in descending order, highest at the top) and selected the top 10 funds.

Table 4:

Coverage Ratio (Distributions Vs. Earnings)

The coverage ratio is derived by dividing the earnings per share by the distribution amount for a specific period. Please note that in some cases, the coverage ratio may be a bit inaccurate since the "earnings per share" may be three to six months old. But in most cases, it's fairly accurate. Furthermore, the coverage ratio is not critical for pure equity funds as they generate very little dividend income, and they cover most of their distributions from capital gains. However, we sorted our list by coverage ratio and selected the top 10 funds.

Table 5:

Excess Return Over Distribution

If a fund provides a very high distribution but low returns over 3, 5, or 10-year periods, it does not help the long-term interests of the investor. In simple terms, the fund is just overpaying the distributions and hurting the NAV in the long term. That is why we calculate a factor we like to call "excess return." This excess return is what is provided by the fund over and above the distribution rate over a specified time period. We calculate it by subtracting the distribution rate from the average of the three-year and five-year NAV returns. In this list, we included the top 10 funds.

Table 6:

Total Weight (Quality Score) Calculated Up to This Point

Note: The Total Weight calculation is not fully completed at this point since we have not considered the 10-year NAV return. However, we select the top 15 names based on current calculations.

Table 7:

From the selections so far, we have 75 funds in total (tables 1-7).

We will need to see if there are any duplicates among them. In our current list of 75 funds, there were 26 duplicates, meaning there are funds that appeared more than once. The following names appear twice (or more):

Appeared twice: AIO, BANX, BGR, BRW, EDF, EMF, EOD, JCE, PDT, SRV, UTF, and XFLT (12 duplicates).

Appeared three times: CSQ, EMO, EOS, GAM, PDX, and TWN (12 duplicates).

Appeared four times: EIC, GGN (6 duplicates).

Once we remove 30 duplicate rows, we are left with 45 (75- 30) funds.

Note: It may be worthwhile to mention here that just because a fund has appeared multiple times does not necessarily make it an attractive candidate. Sometimes, a fund may appear multiple times simply for the wrong reasons, like a high current discount, a high excess discount, or a very high distribution rate that may not be sustainable. However, during the second filtering stage, it may not score well on the overall quality score due to other factors, like a poor track record. That said, if a fund has appeared four times or more, it may be worth a second look.

Narrowing Down to Just 10 Funds:

In our list of funds, we may already have some of the best probable candidates. However, so far, they have been selected based on one (or two) criteria that each may be good at. That's not nearly enough. So, we will apply a combination of criteria by applying weights to eight factors to calculate the total quality score and filter out the best ones.

We will apply weights to each of the eight criteria:

Criteria

Max. Weight

Comment

Baseline expense

5.0

Current distribution rate

7.5

Excess discount/premium

5.0

3-YR NAV return

5.0

5-YR NAV return

5.0

10-YR NAV return or 10-YR Total return

5.0

If less than ten years of history, an average of three and five-year returns is taken.

Excess NAV return over distribution rate

5.0

Adjusted Coverage Ratio

7.5

This factor is adjusted for certain factors. The adjustment is performed based on the type of fund, such as equity and sector funds.

Once we have calculated the weights, we combine them to calculate the "Total Combined Weight," also called the "Quality Score."

The sorted list (spreadsheet) of 45 funds on the "combined total weight or quality score" is attached here.

File-for-export_-_10_Best_CEFs_-_Feb_2026.xlsx

10-Positions Portfolio of The Month:

Before we get to the final ten, we will narrow down our list to 20 names. So, we sorted our table based on the sector and then the quality score. Furthermore, in this round of selections, we mostly pick one or two top funds from each sector (based on quality score). There is a bit of subjective judgment, as we tend to prioritize funds that pay regular and consistent distributions on a monthly or quarterly basis. We also weed out any fund that may have a very poor track record in terms of NAV performance. Funds that may have inconsistent dividends (even if they are high) generally do not make it to our top list. Furthermore, be aware that many times, single-country funds score high in our rankings, but most of them pay variable dividends on an annual or semi-annual basis. In addition, being single-country funds, they can be inherently riskier since their future returns are tied to just one country, be it economic, regulatory, or geopolitical factors. For these reasons, they generally do not make it to our top 5 lists, but they do appear on our list of 20. Individual investors could consider them based on their goals.

Here's the list of the top 20 selections (from different asset classes) in the order of sector:

Table 8:

10-Best-CEFs of the Month

In the end, if we only want to select ten funds, we will need to apply our subjective judgment to some degree. While we narrow down this list to ten names, we would be mindful to keep the list as diversified as possible in terms of sectors and asset classes. Since this step is somewhat subjective, the choice would differ from person to person. Nonetheless, here are the selections for this month, based on our perspective (in order of Quality Score):

Here's the list of the top 10 selections this month (in order of sector):

(EOS), (SCD), (JRI), (EOD), (EIC), (AIO), (UTF), (PEO), (HQL), and (GAM).

Table-9:

Some information about the selections:

We will only briefly describe the selected funds. Since there are 10 of them, we will not be providing a very detailed analysis of them.

Here are some details on many of our selections:

(EOS) Eaton Vance Enhanced Equity Income II:

When it comes to covered call funds, it is hard to beat Eaton Vance funds. Also, EOS is one of the best funds in its category. Its high exposure to the technology sector has definitely helped the fund to shine in the last 10 years. It currently holds only about 50 companies and overwrites (sells options) on roughly 50% of its portfolio to generate income and reduce volatility. The distribution yield is attractive at 8.3%, and currently offers a decent discount of -6%. The fund uses no leverage, and its expenses are comparable to those of its competitors. The past performance record is solid, and it has returned 22%, 11%, and 14% (annualized) over the last 3, 5, and 10-year periods.

(SCD) LMP Capital and Income

SCD is a fairly diversified fund invested in equity as well as fixed-income securities from many sectors. However, nearly 73% of the assets are in equity stocks from many sectors.

The fund is categorized under "Global Allocation," but over 85% is invested in U.S. securities. Broadly, the current allocation is as follows:

  • 73% Common Stocks, mostly US-based, with 16% Financials, 14% Technology, 12% Industrial, 12% Energy, and 8% Healthcare
  • 7.6% MLPs
  • 7% Preferred/Convertible
  • 6% Equity REITs
  • 3.5% Bonds.

The yield is attractive at 9% plus, and the current discount is -8%.

(JRI) Nuveen Real Asset Income & Growth Fund

The fund JRI is a global fund offered by the Nuveen group. It invests in real asset-related companies, including equity stocks, preferred, and debt securities. Real asset-related investments could include companies that are engaged in owning, developing, or operating infrastructure projects or facilities, as well as REITs. Nearly 50-55% of the assets are invested in the U.S.-based companies. The fund uses a significant amount of leverage (roughly 30%) and is very well diversified with nearly 450 holdings. The investments are roughly 45%:55% in real estate vs infrastructure.

The fund has just announced a rights offering, and that is one reason that the discount has widened to nearly -8%. The yield is attractive at 12% plus.

(AIO) Virtus AI & Tech Opp Fund:

This is a fund focused on AI (Artificial Intelligence) and technology companies. But it comes with a unique flavor of combining both the equity and convertible securities, as well as some bonds, based on market conditions. The fund also uses modest leverage of roughly 12% and has performed very well in the last three years. It provides a decent distribution yield of just under 8% and is currently trading at an attractive discount of roughly -10%. This fund was included in December/January as well, but recently the price has come under pressure, and the discount has widened somewhat.

(EIC) Eagle Point Income Co:

EIC is probably the riskiest fund in this selection of 10 funds. The fund uses high leverage of 32% in the form of preferred stock. The fund primarily invests in junior debt tranches of CLOs (Collateralized Loan Obligations). In addition, it may invest up to 35% of total assets in CLO equity securities and related securities.

Due to the decline in interest rates, similar to its peers, the fund has been reducing its distribution amount. The monthly distribution has come down from $0.20 a share to $0.11, a 45% reduction. This has caused the price to fall during most of 2025, and that has continued in 2026, but the pace has slowed down. So, it has been brutal for someone who acquired the shares prior to 2024. However, the yield is still very attractive for the new buyers at 13.2%, in spite of the lower distribution amount. The discount has widened to very high levels at -24%. With reduced distribution, the current distribution is fully covered by the NII (net investment income). However, on a full nine-month basis (January to September), it only covered to the extent of 75%, as the distribution was much higher at the beginning of last year. We think that after significant correction, the price and yield are attractive. However, it is quite likely that the distribution amount may further fall if the interest rates decline further, so this fund should only be accumulated in multiple lots on a dollar-cost-average basis.

(EOD) Allspring Global Dividend Opportunity Fund:

The international funds of all types have done well during the year 2025, and that trend is continuing in 2026. This fund is selected to provide exposure to global equity as well as fixed income. The fund is invested roughly 80% in global equities with a focus on dividends, and the rest in fixed income (18%) and cash equivalents (2%). The equity portion is invested in 70-80 companies spread across many sectors and segments. The fund also employs an options strategy on a portion of the equity portfolio to enhance income and to generate gains on call options. The fund also uses a modest leverage of just under 15%.

The allocation to the U.S. is roughly 65% of the total, and the rest is invested in countries such as the U.K., France, Japan, China, Germany, Italy, Canada, Taiwan, and Brazil. The largest sector is information Technology at 25%, followed by Financials and Communications.

The yield is decent at 8.5%, and the discount is close to -8%.

(UTF) Cohen & Steers Infrastructure Fund:

This is one of the most popular Utility and Infrastructure funds out there in the CEF space, besides the Reaves Utility Income fund (UTG). However, UTF appears to offer better value currently compared to UTG, even though both have appreciated quite a bit in the last 12 months.

The fund invests in infrastructure companies, which consist of utilities, pipelines, toll roads, airports, railroads, ports, and telecommunications companies. The fund offers a close to 7% yield and a discount of roughly -7%. The fund offers a very reliable distribution payout as it has paid consistent and growing distributions since its inception.

(PEO) Adams Natural Resources Fund:

If you like to own some of the large-cap energy majors at a discount, you can't beat the PEO fund offered by the Adams group. It is a very nice fund to hold the energy majors, and that too at good discounts (currently hovering around -9%). This fund provides a diversified exposure to large energy companies. At the same time, there is some over-concentration at the top, given the fact that the two oil majors, Exxon Mobil (XOM) and Chevron (CVX), together represent nearly 38% of the total assets. The yield has come down somewhat in recent months, but it is still attractive at it 7.5%. Please keep in mind that this is an energy sector-specific fund, and hence, one should allocate accordingly.

(HQL) abrdn Life Sciences Investors

The fund had not done too well in recent years, from 2022 to 2024. However, the fund has recovered in the last year and gained roughly 23% in the previous 12 months, excluding nearly 13% dividends.

The fund recently increased the distribution amounts, and the distribution yield is very attractive at 13.35%. It also offers a discount of -8.7%.

The fund uses almost zero leverage and invests in well-known names from the biotechnology sector. This fund has managed to pay a consistent distribution, but mostly from the capital gains and, to some extent, ROC (return of capital).

Some of the top holdings are Amgen (AMGN), Vaxcyte (PCVX), UniQure NV (QURE), Insmed Inc (INSM), Regeneron (REGN), Gilead (GILD), Vertex (VRTX), and BioMarin (BMRN).

(GAM) General American Investors:

GAM is our selection for the core U.S. equity fund for this month. It should be noted that the fund pays annually in the month of December, and the payment is variable from one year to another. Based on the distribution paid in December 2025, the yield is quite attractive at over 10%. The current discount is close to -11%. Income investors who like to have regular quarterly (or monthly) distributions should look elsewhere.

The primary investment objective of the fund is to seek capital appreciation, with income only a secondary objective. The fund invests in equity securities with growth potential at reasonable valuations. The fund also uses a modest leverage in the form of preferred stock.

CEF-Specific Investment Risks:

It goes without saying that CEFs generally have some additional risks. This section is specifically relevant for investors who are new to CEF investing, but in general, all CEF investors should be aware of it. For more details on these specific risks, please read our blog post on CEFs.

  • Use of high leverage and high fees
  • High volatility (compared to the broader market)
  • Premium over NAVs (market price higher than the NAV)
  • Asset-specific concentration risk.

Concluding Thoughts:

The broader market, as represented by the S&P500, provides a dismal yield of less than 1.20%. Many income investors and retirees can't survive on that kind of income. For income investors, we recommend building a core bucket of DGI (Dividend growth) stocks and supplementing it with a basket of CEFs to increase the overall income.

We use our screening process to highlight the best closed-end funds for investment each month. Our filtering process demands that our selections have an above-average long-term performance record, offer an average of roughly 8% distributions, and are relatively cheaper with reasonable discounts. We have also provided a larger list of ten CEFs from many different asset classes.

This month, as a group, the selected 10 best funds are offering an average distribution rate of 8.70% (as of 01/16/2026).
